Award.AwardTitle: Tomorrow's Teachers with Dual Degrees in Mathematics and Mathematics Education (TDM)2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Tomorrow's Teachers with Dual Degrees in Mathematics and Mathematics Education is aggressively working to double the number of secondary mathematics teachers graduating from the University of Missouri's undergraduate mathematics teacher education program through the recruitment of mathematics majors into mathematics teaching careers, preparation of these individuals to teach high school mathematics aligned with national standards, and support of mathematics teachers in their induction years. Scholarships are being offered to 15 participants in each of three cohorts (Years 3, 4, and 5), for a total of 45 unique participants over the course of the project. Scholars are being provided summer mathematics teaching internships, dual degree programs (B.S. in Mathematics and B.S. Ed. in Mathematics Education), and $10,000 annual scholarships for those committed to teaching mathematics in high-needs school districts. To increase teacher retention, the project is developing a cadre of mentor teachers in 22 partner schools and supporting Noyce Scholars' participation in professional mathematics teacher conferences. The intellectual merit of this project is based on the qualifications and commitment of project personnel to inform our understanding about recruiting, preparing, and retaining more highly qualified secondary mathematics teachers. The project team has a substantial record of scholarship, partner schools have a rich history of collaboration with the University of Missouri. The project's broader impacts include: (1) improvement in the quality and quantity of mathematics teachers for Missouri schools; (2) building of new sustainable models for the recruitment, preparation, and retention of mathematics teachers to meet the teacher shortage; (3) expansion and deepening of relationships between MU mathematicians, mathematics teacher educators, and K-12 teachers and administrators; and (4) the dissemination of findings from the external evaluation via conference presentations and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tomorrow’s Teachers with Dual Degrees in Mathematics and Mathematics Education sought to recruit more highly qualified STEM undergraduates into mathematics teaching careers, prepare these individuals to teach mathematics aligned with national standards, and support mathematics teachers in their induction years. Using a multifaceted marketing approach, the project team was successful in recruiting more highly-qualified STEM undergraduates into mathematics teaching careers through the teaching internships and Noyce Scholars program. Interest in the teaching profession was spurred by internships that afforded opportunities for STEM majors to work with high school mathematics students in summer remediation and recovery programs, aimed at closing the “achievement gap”. Over the seven years, 21 scholars participated in the scholarship program, including many who participated in two consecutive years. Since inception, the project yielded a larger than expected pool of majors from which to draw Noyce Scholars—146 Secondary Mathematics Education majors and 226 Mathematics majors—suggesting that the Noyce program had an impact on number of students choosing to pursue degrees in Mathematics Education and Mathematics. Concomitantly, there was an overall increase in the number of students who declared dual-degree majors, climbing from 1 in the first year of the project to a high-mark of 22 in Year 4. The dual-degree programs enhanced the rigor of the mathematics side of secondary mathematics education majors and increased the number of mathematics majors pursuing teaching. Noyce Scholars were trained in the University of Missouri’s high-regarded educator preparation program that features a three-course mathematics methods sequence, mathematics coursework, and field experiences that collectively exceed requirements for teaching licensure in Missouri. Mathematics methods courses focused on designing instruction that embodies the Common Core State Standards and Standards for Mathematical Practices, research-based teaching practices, formative assessment, short- and long-term planning, and classroom management. To support these newly trained teachers, the project sponsored professional development and networking opportunities for Noyce Fellows and their mentor teachers. Noyce Fellows participated in Noyce Summits, regional and/or annual meetings of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, and were trained in cognitive coaching and co-teaching workshops. To date, nearly all Noyce Fellows have fulfilled or are fulfilling their obligation to teach mathematics in high-needs school districts. With a more robust content knowledge of mathematics and serving in high-needs school districts, there is a strong potential that Noyce Fellows will boost achievement in high school mathematics and increase the number of students who pursue STEM fields following high school graduation. Similarly, with training in cognitive coaching as well as co-teaching, Noyce Fellows and their mentor teachers have the potential to increase retention rates of the teaching force, an historic problem facing the teaching profession.
